CARDINAL . LAW ( byggnadslagen CARDINAL:CARDINAL - " LAW " ) is the main legal instrument governing planning in respect of the use of land for construction and urban development . It provides for the drawing up of a master plan ( generalplan ) , which establishes within a municipality the framework for other and more detailed plans , namely city plans ( stadsplaner ) and building plans ( byggnadsplaner ) .

As in the present case , a municipal council may draw up an area plan , instead of a master plan . The manner in which area plans are elaborated and their content are not expressly governed by LAW but general principles of administrative law are , of course , applicable .
CARDINAL . ORG The issue of expropriation permits is governed by LAW . Under LAW , LAW , such a permit is normally granted by the Government .

For cases like the present , the grounds justifying the issue of a permit are stated in LAW , section CARDINAL , of the CARDINAL LAW as amended by LAW ) , which reads as follows ( translation from NORP ) :

" Expropriation is allowed in order to enable a municipality to acquire rights over land which is needed , as a result of future societal requirements , for urban development ( tätbebyggelse ) or constructions in connection with such development . ... Within areas of urban development expropriation is allowed only if there is reason to assume that , within a foreseeable time , the area will be subject to building or other construction activities which are deemed important in the general interest , or if there is an urgent necessity for the municipality to acquire rights over the land for the furthering of planned building or for any other similar reason . ... "

However , a permit must not be granted if the purpose of the expropriation can be attained by other appropriate means , or if the disadvantages of the expropriation would outweigh , from general and individual points of view , its advantages ( LAW , section CARDINAL , of the CARDINAL Act ) .

ORG Under LAW , section CARDINAL , of the CARDINAL LAW , the sole effect in law of the issue of an expropriation permit is to confer on its holder an entitlement to acquire the designated property . Consequently , the issue of a permit leaves legally intact the owner ’s right to use , sell , let or mortgage his property ( see also paragraph CARDINAL below ) , and does not automatically lead to expropriation .

Before the expropriation can be finalised , its terms - such as the compensation to be paid to the owner and the boundaries of the expropriated area - have to be settled in proceedings before a real estate court . Moreover , the expropriation is not completed until the compensation - in principle equivalent to the market value - has been paid .

However , LAW , section CARDINAL , provides that it may be extended in special circumstances , or reduced if the owner so requests and establishes that the inconvenience for him in the expropriation remaining pending has increased significantly . No decision to reduce the time - limit can be taken until DATE has elapsed since the issue of the expropriation permit .

CARDINAL . ORG Some reasons for restricting the time - limit and , hence , the duration of the validity of expropriation permits were stated in LAW , page CARDINAL , which led to the CARDINAL Act ( translation from NORP ) :

" Naturally , the mere issue of an expropriation permit often places [ the owner ] in a state of uncertainty . CARDINAL . Generally speaking , the NORP administration is not subject to supervision by the ordinary courts . Those courts entertain proceedings against the ORG only in contractual matters , on questions of extra - contractual liability and , under some statutes , in respect of administrative decisions .

Judicial review of the administration ’s acts is therefore primarily a matter for administrative courts . These courts comprise CARDINAL levels : the county administrative courts ( länsrätterna ) ; the administrative courts of appeal ( kammarrätterna ) ; and ORG ( regeringsrätten ) . They are composed of independent judges and enjoy , as a rule , wide powers which enable them not only to set aside administrative acts but also to vary or substitute them . There is , however , an important exception to this principle , in that no appeal may be made against decisions of the Government ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .
